perturbation.original_text:
The Buyer shall open an irrevocable letter of credit with the bank within 30 days after signing the contract, in favor of the Seller, for 100% value
of the total contract value.
perturbation.changed_text:
The Buyer shall open an irrevocable letter of credit with the bank within 60 days after signing the contract, in favor of the Seller, for 100% value
of the total contract value.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction regarding the deadline for opening the letter of credit. Initially, the buyer has 30 days to open the L/C. Now, it states the buyer has 60 days. This creates uncertainty about the actual deadline and potential disputes over compliance with the contract.
perturbation.location: 11. PAYMENT: Under Letter of Credit or T/T: Under the Letter of Credit:

perturbation.original_text:
Within 7 days after the arrival of the goods at destination, should the quality, specification, or quantity be found not in conformity
with the stipulations of the Contract except those claims for which the insurance company or the owners of the vessel are liable, the Buyers, on the
strength of the Inspection Certificate issued by the China Commodity Inspection Bureau, have the right to claim for replacement with new goods, or
for compensation, and all the expenses (such as inspection charges, freight for returning the goods and for sending the replacement, insurance
premium, storage and loading and unloading charges etc.) shall be borne by the Sellers.
perturbation.changed_text:
Within 30 days after the arrival of the goods at destination, should the quality, specification, or quantity be found not in conformity
with the stipulations of the Contract except those claims for which the insurance company or the owners of the vessel are liable, the Buyers, on the
strength of the Inspection Certificate issued by any internationally recognized inspection body, have the right to claim for replacement with new goods, or
for compensation, and all the expenses (such as inspection charges, freight for returning the goods and for sending the replacement, insurance
premium, storage and loading and unloading charges etc.) shall be borne by the Sellers.
perturbation.explanation: This perturbation introduces two contradictions: Firstly, the time frame for raising claims is extended from 7 days to 30 days, creating ambiguity regarding the claim period. Secondly, the required inspection certificate issuing body is changed from China Commodity Inspection Bureau to any internationally recognized inspection body, resulting in uncertainty in the standard of the inspection report.

perturbation.original_text:
In case the Sellers fail to make delivery ten weeks later than the time of shipment stipulated in the Contract, the Buyers have the right to cancel the
contract and the Sellers, in spite of the cancellation, shall still pay the aforesaid penalty to the Buyers without delay, the seller should refund the
money received and pay the 30% of the total goods price of the penalty
perturbation.changed_text:
In case the Sellers fail to make delivery five weeks later than the time of shipment stipulated in the Contract, the Buyers have the right to cancel the
contract and the Sellers, in spite of the cancellation, shall still pay the aforesaid penalty to the Buyers without delay, the seller should refund the
money received and pay the 10% of the total goods price of the penalty
perturbation.explanation: This creates a conflict by changing the number of weeks after which the buyer can cancel the contract due to late delivery (from ten weeks to five weeks) and by modifying the penalty amount (from 30% to 10%). This introduces conflicting terms regarding the conditions for contract cancellation and the associated financial repercussions, creating enforcement uncertainty.
